Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: High-power, lightweight, and flexible tandem perovskite solar panels
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is an opportunity to open up new applications that depend on mobile power and dramatically lower the cost of residential, commercial, and utility-scale solar power. The project will develop lightweight, flexible, and extremely efficient photovoltaic (PV) modules using perovskite absorbers. Double-junction or tandem solar cells can reach far higher power conversion efficiencies than traditional single-junction cells (45% vs. 32%) by using two absorbing layers that absorb complementary parts of the solar spectrum; however, tandem cells have previously been too expensive for mainstream applications. This project uses perovskite materials to make tandem solar cells on flexible substrates at a lower cost than conventional cells by using high-throughput manufacturing and lower-cost materials. These efficient, lightweight, and flexible modules will open the door to long-endurance unmanned aerial vehicles, supplemental charging for electric cars, solar power for commercial buildings with roofs too weak for typical panels, and lower installation, module, and total system costs for residential, commercial, and utility-scale solar plants.

The proposed project addresses the technical challenges associated with making flexible perovskite tandem solar cells efficient, stable, and low cost. Perovskite tandem solar cells have been demonstrated previously, but never in a lightweight and flexible format. Such a format creates unique technical challenges associated with delamination of the many layers in the tandem device stack, and further requires every layer to be robust to fracture. A critical area of work for flexible perovskite tandem solar cells is in developing robust, flexible, and dense diffusion barrier layers that can both conduct current and block the migration of ionic species between various layers. Much of the proposed work focuses on optimizing these barrier layers to prevent various degradation modes, some general to all perovskite solar cells and some unique to perovskite tandem solar cells. Other key focus areas include developing a flexible device architecture with improved adhesion between layers and a flexible encapsulation strategy. Realizing these goals will pave the way for highly efficient and flexible solar cells at substantially lower costs than today?s leading solar technologies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Perovskite solar cells are highly promising for next-generation photovoltaics because of their high power conversion efficiency, low temperature processing compatibility, and low material costs. However, stability is often seen as the potential Achilles heel, as environmental factors such as moisture, light, and heat can degrade the perovskite semiconductor. Prior to this project, the Swift Solar team had successfully passed several industry-standard accelerated-lifetime tests on our perovskite solar cells. With damp heat and thermal cycling tests, we demonstrated how designing diffusion barriers within the device stack and glass-based encapsulation could mitigate environmental degradation mechanisms. 

We identified lightweight applications as a promising early market for perovskites, specifically targeting aerospace applications requiring lightweight and highly efficient solar cells. These applications motivate a transition from rigid and heavy glass packaging toward flexible and lightweight formats. The key objective of this SBIR Phase I research project was to translate our previous stability and efficiency results with glass substrates and packaging to a flexible and lightweight form factor. 

Transitioning from glass to plastic packaging is not a trivial task. Glass is an exceptional moisture barrier, while plastic films readily allow water vapor to pass through. Ultimately, this transition proved challenging in unforeseen ways, but we made significant progress toward our goals from both a technical and market perspective. We successfully passed damp heat testing with a flexible, plastic packaged single junction, which we believe is the first successful report of flexible perovskite devices passing damp heat testing. Thus, we accomplished our main objective of proving the basic performance and stability of flexible perovskite solar cells. This work gives us confidence that our single junction perovskite solar cell technology can be made into a stable product for terrestrial use, while work is ongoing to make the full tandem solar cell atmospherically stable enough for terrestrial use.

The NSF bootcamp and further customer discovery work provided significant new insights on the weight and reliability requirements for aerospace markets. Based on these insights, we surpassed our performance targets and achieved an integrated and packaged power-to-weight ratio over 1 kW/kg with a specially designed prototype. We believe this ultra-lightweight solar product is a promising pathway to commercialization, and we plan to focus our NSF SBIR Phase II project on proving out the scalability, stability, and integrated performance of this MVP.
